question.title: Write Java code to crash the java virtual machine

node.contents: No, that doesn't **crash** the VM. You can easily trigger memory overflow though with a infinite loop.

astNode.text: No, that doesn't **crash** the VM. You can easily trigger memory overflow though with a infinite loop.

node.contents: `System.exit()` just terminates VM - This is a duplicate question - look here [How do you crash a JVM?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/65200/how-do-you-crash-a-jvm)

astNode.text: `System.exit()` just terminates VM - This is a duplicate question - look here [How do you crash a JVM?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/65200/how-do-you-crash-a-jvm)

node.contents: I can include the code during my development.

astNode.text: I can include the code during my development.

node.contents: This interview question _does not make sense_ on the first place!

astNode.text: This interview question _does not make sense_ on the first place!

node.contents: Yeah but memory overflow is a program crash, not a VM crash. To have a genuine JVM crash you'd have to find and use an actual JVM bug - obviously the JVM crashing isn't part of normal expected runtime.

astNode.text: Yeah but memory overflow is a program crash, not a VM crash. To have a genuine JVM crash you'd have to find and use an actual JVM bug - obviously the JVM crashing isn't part of normal expected runtime.

node.contents: @Thor84no, couldn't agree with you more.

astNode.text: @Thor84no, couldn't agree with you more.

node.contents: In one of my past interviews , someone asked me to write a code to crash the JVM. I said System.exit(). Is this correct? Are there any better answers?

astNode.text: In one of my past interviews , someone asked me to write a code to crash the JVM. I said System.exit(). Is this correct? Are there any better answers?

node.contents: clarification: I can include my piece of code during development and deploy. It is not that JVM is already running and I have to write a hacking code to crash the other JVM.

astNode.text: clarification: I can include my piece of code during development and deploy. It is not that JVM is already running and I have to write a hacking code to crash the other JVM.

node.contents: +1 for the follow up questions. I should have asked these :)

astNode.text: +1 for the follow up questions. I should have asked these :)

node.contents: I don't think politely requesting that the JVM terminates really counts as "crashing" it. You'd have to ask the interviewew exactly what they meant by "crash". For example:

astNode.text: I don't think politely requesting that the JVM terminates really counts as "crashing" it. You'd have to ask the interviewew exactly what they meant by "crash". For example:

node.contents:
• Would forcing a stack overflow or an out-of-memory condition count?
  • Can you use JNI or any other sort of native code?
  • Tell me what exact VM version you're running, and I'll try to find a JIT compiler bug...

astNode.text:
• Would forcing a stack overflow or an out-of-memory condition count?
  • Can you use JNI or any other sort of native code?
  • Tell me what exact VM version you're running, and I'll try to find a JIT compiler bug...

node.contents: (There have certainly been JIT compiler problems in the past - ages ago I had a pure Java program which would consistently segfault, but could be "fixed" by making what looked like a no-op change.)

astNode.text: (There have certainly been JIT compiler problems in the past - ages ago I had a pure Java program which would consistently segfault, but could be "fixed" by making what looked like a no-op change.)

node.contents: Isn't this the same as throwing an error?

astNode.text: Isn't this the same as throwing an error?

node.contents: This is just running out of Java stack or heap memory, it's not the same as crashing the JVM. See Peter Lawrey's answer to what a JVM crash looks like.

astNode.text: This is just running out of Java stack or heap memory, it's not the same as crashing the JVM. See Peter Lawrey's answer to what a JVM crash looks like.

node.contents: The definition of "crash" is somewhat subjective. The Unsafe scheme is something I hadn't thought of. But running the JVM out of internal heap would likely result in a "true" crash.

astNode.text: The definition of "crash" is somewhat subjective. The Unsafe scheme is something I hadn't thought of. But running the JVM out of internal heap would likely result in a "true" crash.

node.contents: (Note that the JVM "usually" handles infinite recursion with an only an unhandled exception shutdown, but it's highly context dependent.)

astNode.text: (Note that the JVM "usually" handles infinite recursion with an only an unhandled exception shutdown, but it's highly context dependent.)

node.contents: Simple: Either blow the stack with infinite recursion or run the JVM out of object heap.

astNode.text: Simple: Either blow the stack with infinite recursion or run the JVM out of object heap.

node.contents: More complicated would be to run the JVM out of internal heap -- you could probably do this with some sort of class loading loop, but it would take work.

astNode.text: More complicated would be to run the JVM out of internal heap -- you could probably do this with some sort of class loading loop, but it would take work.

node.contents: Otherwise you'd have to exploit some sort of bug, or at least drop into JNI.

astNode.text: Otherwise you'd have to exploit some sort of bug, or at least drop into JNI.

elements.contents: public class Recur { public static void main(String[] argv) { recur(); } static void recur() { Object[] o = null; try { while(true) { Object[] newO = new Object[1]; newO[0] = o; o = newO; } } finally { recur(); } } } C:\JavaTools>java Recur # # An unexpected error has been detected by Java Runtime Environment: # # EXCEPTION_STACK_OVERFLOW (0xc00000fd) at pc=0x000000006dad5c3d, pid=6816, tid =5432 # # Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (11.2-b01 mixed mode windows-amd64) # Problematic frame: # V [jvm.dll+0x2e5c3d] # # An error report file with more information is saved as: # C:\JavaTools\hs_err_pid6816.log # # If you would like to submit a bug report, please visit: # http://java.sun.com/webapps/bugreport/crash.jsp #

node.contents: With Unsafe the chance is higher to get a SIGSEGV than a normal execution.

node.contents: @Karussell You are more likely to get a SIGBUS unless you are accessing the first page by accident, not that it's better.

node.contents: You can use the Unsafe class which is unsafe to use as you might guess.

astNode.text: You can use the Unsafe class which is unsafe to use as you might guess.

elements.contents: public static void main(String... args) throws Exception { getUnsafe().getByte(0); } private static Unsafe getUnsafe() throws NoSuchFieldException, IllegalAccessException { Field theUnsafe = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafe.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) theUnsafe.get(null); }

units.rawText: public static void main(String... args) throws Exception { getUnsafe().getByte(0); } private static Unsafe getUnsafe() throws NoSuchFieldException, IllegalAccessException { Field theUnsafe = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafe.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) theUnsafe.get(null); }

node.contents: I have used this to test when a change has been made to a file. I made the change and crashed the JVM to ensure something else wasn't flushing or something later. Then I check I saw the update I expected.

astNode.text: I have used this to test when a change has been made to a file. I made the change and crashed the JVM to ensure something else wasn't flushing or something later. Then I check I saw the update I expected.

elements.contents: public class StringOutOfMemory { public static void main(String[] args) { int i = 0; StringBuilder s = new StringBuilder("a"); while (true) { s.append("ahgsdgjsdffsdfhsdgfsdfsdsfhdsgksdgkfgsdkfkdghfksdkfsdkfdkjfskdfkjsdfkdksdkdfjksjkhsdfjkfsdkjfsdhjkfsdjkfhdjkfkjsdfkjdsjkfd"); System.out.println(i++); } } }
